The Company manufactures products at its plants, which are located in Forest City, North Carolina, St. Peters, Missouri, and Helmond, The Netherlands. The Company also has hand assembly operations in Costa Rica.
Consistent with the Company's previously announced plans to integrate its three subsidiaries and consolidate its operations, in November 1998, the Company consolidated its UK operations into its Helmond, The Netherlands, facility. In 1999, the Company completed the closure of its Texas and Mexico plants. See "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and results of Operations" and Note 12 to the Company's Consolidated Financial Statements.
The following table sets forth information with respect to the Company's facilities:
The Company's facilities are in good condition and adequate for its present operating needs.
Plastic components are produced at the Company's own manufacturing facilities. In addition, the Company manufactures certain other components used in its products; the remaining components are purchased from outside suppliers. The Company's products are assembled automatically on assembly machines built to the Company's specifications and, at its facilities in Costa Rica, by hand.

Question: Based on the information provided, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the Company's manufacturing and assembly operations as of 1999?

A) The Company operates manufacturing facilities in four countries: USA, Netherlands, Costa Rica, and Mexico.
B) All of the Company's plastic components are produced at its own manufacturing facilities, with no outsourcing.
C) The Company uses a combination of automated assembly machines and hand assembly, with hand assembly operations located in Costa Rica.
D) The Company has consolidated all of its European operations into a single facility in the UK.

Option C is the most accurate statement based on the given information. This directly supports the combination of automated and hand assembly, with hand assembly specifically mentioned in Costa Rica.

Option D is incorrect. The document states that the Company consolidated its UK operations into its Helmond, The Netherlands facility, not the other way around.

Item 2. Properties
We own our principal office and manufacturing facility, which is located in Greenville, South Carolina. This facility contains approximately 188,000 square feet used by the medical and custom products segments and is located on a 13-acre site. We believe that our current manufacturing and storage space is adequate to support our operations during the next several years, depending on sales growth rates.
We also lease 15,000 square feet of warehouse space in Salt Lake City, Utah for use as a distribution center for our medical products segment. We lease this facility on a month-by-month basis at a rate of $7,500 per month.
We consider the South Carolina and Utah facilities to be suitable and adequate for their intended purposes.
In connection with our acquisition of M.C. Healthcare on December 9, 2011, we signed a five-year commitment to lease the 50,000 square foot manufacturing and showroom facility in Beamsville, Ontario, Canada from M.C. Healthcare’s former parent corporation, Thompson Contract Supply Company Limited, at $265,000 per year with an option to buy the property or continue the lease for an additional five years. We consider the Beamsville, Ontario facilities suitable and adequate for the conduct of the business acquired from M.C. Healthcare, which is part of our medical products segment.

As of December 31, 2002, Gardner Denver has nineteen manufacturing plants, three of which are remanufacturing operations, one distribution center, several warehouses and numerous sales offices. The significant facilities are as follows:
The Peachtree City, Georgia facility is currently leased from the Fayette County Development Authority in connection with industrial revenue bond financing. The Company has an option to purchase the property at a nominal price when the bonds are repaid in 2018.

documentation.text:
Item 1. Business
General: The principal business of Regency Realty Corporation (the "Company") is owning, operating and developing grocery anchored neighborhood shopping centers in targeted infill markets in the Southeast. The Company, a Florida corporation organized in 1993, commenced operations as a real estate investment trust in 1993 with the completion of its Initial Public Offering ("IPO"), and was the successor to the real estate business of The Regency Group, Inc. which had operated since 1963. Unless the context requires otherwise, all references to the "Company" include (1) its wholly owned real estate properties, an operating partnership and two joint ventures and (2) Regency Realty Group, Inc. (the "Management Company").
The Company owns and operates 50 commercial real estate properties, 40 of which are anchored by grocery stores. At December 31, 1996, the properties contained 5.5 million square feet ("GLA") and were 95.4% leased. The properties are all located in the Southeast, primarily in Florida (71% of GLA) and Georgia (11% of GLA). At December 31, 1996, approximately 10.2%, 4.6%, 3.3%, and 3% of annualized total rent pertains to leases with Publix, Winn-Dixie, Wal-Mart, and Kroger, respectively. For more specific data and information about the properties owned by the Company see Item 2.

Question: Regency Realty Corporation's business model and portfolio characteristics in 1996 can be best described as:

A) A diversified real estate investment trust with properties across the United States, focusing on office buildings and industrial spaces.

B) A grocery-anchored shopping center REIT with properties predominantly in the Southeast, deriving over 20% of its rent from four major retailers.

C) A residential real estate company specializing in apartment complexes in Florida and Georgia, with a 95.4% occupancy rate.

Answer A is incorrect because the company focuses on the Southeast, not the entire U.S., and specifically on grocery-anchored shopping centers, not office buildings or industrial spaces.

Answer D is incorrect because while the company has operated since 1963, 80% (not 50%) of its properties are grocery-anchored, and the tenant distribution is not even, with four major retailers accounting for a significant portion of the rent.

16.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A company is planning to relocate its operations from Richardson, Texas to Frisco, Texas in April 2008. Based on the information provided, what will be the approximate total rent paid for the new Frisco facility from the relocation date until the lease expiration, assuming the relocation occurs on April 1, 2008?

A) $3,804,720
B) $3,947,397
C) $4,042,515
D) $4,185,192

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
To solve this problem, we need to:
1. Calculate the number of months from April 1, 2008 to January 2015 (lease expiration)
2. Multiply the number of months by the monthly rent

Calculating the months:
- From April 2008 to December 2014: 6 years and 9 months = 81 months
- January 2015: 1 month
Total: 82 months

Monthly rent for the Frisco facility: $47,559

Total rent: 82 * $47,559 = $3,899,838

The closest answer to this calculation is B) $3,947,397.

Options A and C are too low and too high respectively, while D is significantly higher than the calculated amount. B is the best approximation given the available choices.

18.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Calculate the total annual rental cost per square foot for Universal, RAL, and American combined, rounded to the nearest cent.

A) $6.72/sq ft
B) $7.24/sq ft
C) $8.09/sq ft
D) $9.15/sq ft

Correct Answer: C) $8.09/sq ft

Explanation:
To solve this, we need to:
1. Calculate the total rented square footage
2. Calculate the total annual rental cost
3. Divide the total cost by the total square footage

Universal: 182,500 sq ft, $1,223,000/year
RAL: 81,000 sq ft, $797,000/year
American: 48,270 sq ft, $495,000/year

Total square footage: 182,500 + 81,000 + 48,270 = 311,770 sq ft
Total annual rental cost: $1,223,000 + $797,000 + $495,000 = $2,515,000

Cost per square foot: $2,515,000 / 311,770 = $8.0668 per sq ft

Rounded to the nearest cent: $8.09 per sq ft

This question requires careful reading, data extraction, multi-step calculations, and attention to detail in rounding, making it challenging for an exam setting.

51.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A company is analyzing its office space utilization across multiple locations. Given the following information:
- Total leased space: 600,000 sq ft
- Excess space: 300,000 sq ft
- Excess space available for sublease: 70,000 sq ft
- Headquarters space in Boston: 325,000 sq ft
- New York City office space: 132,000 sq ft

What percentage of the company's non-excess leased space is located outside of Boston and New York City?

A) 14.3%
B) 28.6%
C) 47.7%
D) 52.3%

Correct Answer: B) 28.6%

Explanation:
1. Calculate non-excess space: 600,000 - 300,000 = 300,000 sq ft
2. Space in Boston and NYC: 325,000 + 132,000 = 457,000 sq ft
3. Non-excess space outside Boston and NYC: 300,000 - (457,000 - 300,000) = 143,000 sq ft
4. Percentage: (143,000 / 300,000) * 100 = 47.67%
5. 100% - 47.67% = 52.33% (in Boston and NYC)
6. 52.33% / 2 ≈ 28.6% (half of the space in Boston and NYC)

This question requires careful reading, multi-step calculations, and inference from the given data, making it challenging for exam takers.

B) The $12 million annual rental commitment is primarily for the Troy, Ohio facility.
C) The company's leased space for distribution centers represents about 28% of their total occupied space.
D) The capital lease for the Troy, Ohio facility is included in the $12 million annual rental commitment.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
A is incorrect because the total space (4,800,000 + 1,900,000 = 6,700,000) is described as "approximately," not exactly.
B is unlikely because the $12 million is described as covering "minimum annual rental commitments under real estate leases," plural, suggesting it's for multiple properties, not primarily the Troy facility.
C is correct: 1,900,000 / (4,800,000 + 1,900,000) = 0.2836, or about 28% of the total occupied space.
D is incorrect because capital leases are typically not included in rental commitments, as they are treated more like owned assets for accounting purposes.

Option C is the most likely to be true based on the given information and requires careful calculation and understanding of the provided data.

Item 2. Properties
Our principal facility and corporate headquarters is located at the Natural Energy Laboratory of Hawaii Authority (“NELHA”) at Keahole Point in Kailua-Kona, Hawaii. Option D is close but not precise - while the financials may be consolidated, they are likely not simply combined into a single report, but rather presented as part of a larger, more complex financial statement structure referenced in Item 14.

ITEM 2. PROPERTIES
During the third quarter of fiscal 1994, the Company exercised its option to terminate its lease for its plant and office space that was due to expire July 1999. Simultaneous with the termination, the Company signed a three year lease covering approximately 28,000 square feet in the same facility, that expires November 4, 1997. The Company has an option to extend the lease for an additional thirty-six months. As part of its restructuring described in "BUSINESS" above, the Company recorded a charge of $180,000 to reflect excess capacity at the Berkeley facility, which it intends to vacate and sublease. Management believes that the current facility has been developed to be highly suitable to the Company's mix of manufacturing, office and storage requirements, however that it is excessive in light of its restructuring described above.
Minimum lease payments for each of the next two fiscal years (through termination of the lease) are $184,000 per year. There are no future minimum lease payments for any periods thereafter. Net rental expenses under operating leases were $193,000, $294,000 and $300,000 for fiscal 1995, 1994 and 1993, respectively. In addition, the Company leases space for its Printer Development Center in Incline Village, Nevada, however, subsequent to year end, the Company exercised its option to terminate the lease.
